message.content: This question requires an understanding of the negative effects of pollution on the environment. When pollutants such as chemicals and toxins are released into water bodies, they can contaminate the fish living in those waters. As a result, the fish may become inedible and unfit for human consumption. Option (B) is not always the case as polluted water may not always have an obvious taste. Option (C) is unrelated as the reporting of pollution in papers does not directly relate to the consequence of pollution itself. Option (D) is unrelated as trash overflowing is not a direct consequence of polluting.

This question involves understanding the potential effects of pollution on the environment. When pollutants enter bodies of water, such as rivers or lakes, they can contaminate the fish living in those waters. As a result, the fish may become inedible, meaning they are not safe to eat. Option (B) is incorrect because the taste of water is not directly related to pollution. Option (C) is unrelated because the reporting of pollution in newspapers does not directly affect the environment. Option (D) is also unrelated as overflowing trash is not directly caused by pollution.
